node.text:
The anglerfish is one of the most famous deep-sea animals. This bulbous beast has a “fishing pole” projecting from its head. This pole is called the “illicium”, and is made from the front part of the fish’s dorsal fin. In deep-sea anglers, the illicium has a bioluminescent bulb, called the “esca,” at the end, which it uses to attract small fishes and crustaceans. Each species has its own unique combination of illicium and esca. Some have short and sturdy illicia with a small rounded esca, while others have long and thread-like illicium with a feathery esca. Each model is suited to different methods of fishing: the long, thin models are used to “trawl” for food along the seafloor, where shorter ones pull prey from the midwaters. 

A fish fishing for its own food might seem like a weird choice, but the method is suited perfectly to the deep sea. In the vast and expansive waters of the midnight zone, food is few and far between. Pursuing prey would waste a lot of energy. Instead, a hungry anglerfish merely sets out its bioluminescent bait and waits. The glowing esca entices small fishes and crustaceans to come closer, then the anglerfish’s massive mouth and sharp teeth snap shut for a meal.

node.title: Anglerfishes are the couch potato's hero

node.text:
This International Polychaete Day, we’re celebrating a worm that likes it hot.

The Pompeii worm (Alvinella pompejana) makes its home at the top of hydrothermal vent “chimneys,” where superheated water belches from within the Earth’s crust delivering a rain of mineral “ash.” Here, large numbers of worms live side by side, each darting in and out of their paper-thin tubes while waving pointy, rust-colored gills.

node.text:
This World Ocean Day, we are celebrating the global ocean that connects us all. 

The deep sea is the largest living space on Earth. Weird and wonderful animals thrive in this cold and dark environment. Between the sunlit surface and the deep seafloor lies an expanse of open water—the midnight zone. A dazzling diversity of creatures drift, swim, and flourish here. These animals live in a world without barriers or borders. Many of these species are found throughout the world’s ocean. For them, there is only one ocean. Our ocean and its inhabitants face a rising tide of threats. Pollution, overfishing, and climate change make for an uncertain future. We’re working to understand the midnight zone and how animals there will navigate these changes. Our ocean needs our help. All life—including us—depends on a healthy ocean.

node.text:
On June 30th, dive behind the scenes of MBARI’s expedition to Sur Ridge during our #LiveFromTheDeep virtual event. MBARI has incredible access to the deep sea right in our backyard, and we want you to come along and explore with us!
 
Just off the coast of northern California—near Big Sur—lies Sur Ridge, an underwater oasis of deep-sea corals and sponge gardens. MBARI’s remotely operated vehicles and state-of-the-art cameras let our scientists see the amazing creatures that call Sur Ridge home, and high-resolution mapping tools create stunning images of the seafloor. 

Join us on June 30 at 11:00 a.m. (PT) and see live footage of the seafloor, ask our scientists and engineers your questions, and find out what it’s really like to have a career exploring the deep ocean.

Tune into the livestream on MBARI’s YouTube, Facebook, or Twitter.

node.title: Take a trip to Sur Ridge

node.text:
Snailfish are flabby, scaleless fishes with tadpole-like bodies, broad fins, and a tiny tail. Well-adapted to a variety of deep-sea habitats—including rocky outcrops, the muddy seafloor, and the midwater—they are a diverse and thriving group with over 400 described species. 

They play an important role as prey and predator in many ecosystems. MBARI has observed over a dozen species of snailfish in the past 34 years of exploration. We suspect there are dozens more out there waiting to be discovered!

node.text: There are hundreds of pathways to an ocean STEM career—and some of them may surprise you. MBARI engineer Emery Nolasco talks about how tinkering and robotics led her to a career working with autonomous underwater vehicles to help scientists study the deep sea. This is the first episode of MBARI’s new video series Navigating STEM, a multimedia, behind-the-scenes look at how MBARI staff found their way to ocean exploration as a career—and where they’re going from here.

node.title: Our newest video series, Navigating STEM, is here! 🎥 🎉

node.text:
Fish are messy inhabitants of their freshwater homes. As they swim, mate, and bump up against obstacles, they leave behind tiny clues pointing to their presence long after they swim away. These sloughed-off cells, waste, and tissue combined with free DNA, algae, and microscopic organisms make up a genetic soup of environmental DNA (eDNA). ⁠
⁠
Sampling, preserving, and analyzing this eDNA is like finding nature’s fingerprint at a crime scene and using it as a tool for smarter freshwater management.MBARI’s “lab-in-a-can” collects and analyzes eDNA, expanding our ability to monitor aquatic health. Learn more in our new interactive infographic! #linkinbio

node.title: MBARI researchers are fishing for genetics. 🎣⁠

node.text:
So we thought we'd celebrate the baby bloom in the deep sea!
⁠
Deep-sea animals have adapted a variety of ways to promote the survival of their young. The babies often come in unusual shapes and sizes, exhibiting features not seen in the adult form. Surprisingly, many larval and juvenile forms of bottom-dwelling species develop in the open ocean; they may disperse long distances along coastlines to decrease resource competition with adult populations or to keep far out of the reach of hungry seafloor predators. Deep-sea babies may look and live very differently from their parents to enhance their chance of survival and may even journey from the seafloor to the surface and back again during a lifecycle.⁠

node.text:
In 2013, after many years spent mapping Monterey Bay and its environs, MBARI and NOAA scientists discovered an underwater oasis—lush with corals and sponges—just 35 kilometers (22 miles) west of Big Sur. This rocky ridge, called Sur Ridge, stands over 500 meters (1,640 feet) tall and stretches over 20 kilometers (12 miles) long—roughly the size of Manhattan. MBARI has been working diligently to create ever more detailed maps of Sur Ridge for more than twenty years to better understand its geologic processes—like underwater landslides—and to monitor the health of the marine life that calls it home—including the impacts of climate change. ⁠
⁠
Data collected by MBARI’s mapping team has helped bring Sur Ridge to life. This animation combines data from ship-based multibeam sonar at 25 meters (80 feet) in resolution, autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) multibeam mapping data at one meter (about three feet) in resolution, and remotely operated vehicle (ROV) mapping lidar data at five centimeters (two inches) in resolution. MBARI scientists worked with Los Angeles film production company Frame 48 to visualize the terrain of Sur Ridge in astonishing detail. These amazing images demonstrate what’s possible when scientists and engineers work together to develop new technology for exploring the deep ocean.

Thanks to the talented visual effects artists at @frame.48 for helping us bring our mapping date to life!

node.text:
The is the California sun star, a voracious predator, and the subject of MBARI's newest addition to our sticker collection! (And yes, this is a giveaway so read on for details on how to enter and win!)⁠
⁠
These sea stars scuttle along the seafloor on an army of tiny tube feet, following the scent of a rotting feast. But this sea star doesn’t just dine on scavenged scraps—it can be a cunning predator. It feasts on crabs, amphipods, worms, and other small invertebrates by trapping them in its arms and swallowing a meal whole.⁠ The surface of the star is also covered in tiny spines lined with pincers that puff up like pom-poms. When something swims too close or crawls on top, those pincers grab tight to help capture potential prey.⁠
⁠
Enter to win one of these splendiferous stickers by following this account and tagging three friends in the comments. The giveaway will run until Wednesday, March 3 and the winners will be announced on Thursday, March 4. Good luck, deep-sea squad!

node.title: Don’t be fooled by this star’s sunny disposition.⁠

node.text:
The open ocean and deep sea are extremely challenging environments, and MBARI couldn’t do ground-breaking science without our innovative engineers and operations staff to take us there. We’re celebrating Emery, the women of MBARI, and all #WomenInScience for paving the way for a new generation of curious problem solvers.⁠
⁠
Stay tuned for the pilot episode of our new series Navigating STEM, a multimedia series exploring how MBARI staff has found their way to ocean exploration as a career—and where they’re going from here.⁠
⁠
In Emery’s words, “We have so many questions, and if we only have one or two or three people answering those questions or coming up with the ideas, we're maybe not capturing all of the different perspectives.”⁠
⁠
“You're the person who's going to ask those questions and bring those new ideas to the table. And the world needs that, the world needs you and your perspective and what you bring.”⁠ #womeninscienceday

node.title: Meet Emery Nolasco, an underwater robot engineer, and problem solver!

node.text: The deep sea—Earth's largest habitat—is home to a host of unique communities and geological features. To help our education and conservation partners at the Monterey Bay Aquarium prepare for their upcoming exhibition Into the Deep: Exploring Our Undiscovered Ocean, we invited their staff to join an expedition to Sur Ridge aboard the R/V Western Flyer. Home to a fantastic array of deep-sea animals, this underwater rocky ridge is just 35 kilometers (about 22 miles) off the Big Sur coast and 800 meters (2,600 feet) below the Pacific’s surface. Researchers from MBARI and NOAA’s Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary first discovered this rich ecosystem in 2013 and have returned multiple times in the last few years to learn more about this fascinating deep-sea environment. We are excited to see how the Aquarium brings Sur Ridge and its marine life to the public in their exhibition in 2022!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by MBARI on August 17, 2021 tagging @montereybayaquarium. May be an image of standing.

node.text:
Microscopic marine life plays a fundamental role in the health of our planet. 🌏⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just like plants on land, tiny phytoplankton use photosynthesis to consume carbon dioxide and convert it into organic matter and oxygen. This biological transformation is called marine primary productivity, and it ebbs and flows in response to changes in our climate. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The sheer scale of the ocean makes it challenging to monitor primary productivity. In a new study in Nature Geoscience, MBARI Senior Scientist Ken Johnson and former MBARI postdoctoral fellow Mariana Bif demonstrated how a fleet of robotic floats can revolutionize our understanding of ocean primary productivity and, ultimately, ocean health.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Learn more on our website (#linkinbio). Images: @montereybayaquarium and @SOCCOMproject⁠⁠

node.text:
This rattail fish swam by to say Happy Monday! ⁠
⁠
Rattails, like the Pacific grenadier, Coryphaenoides acrolepis, are very curious and will come to investigate any disturbance on or around the seafloor. ⁠
⁠
The Pacific grenadier is one of the most common rattail fishes in the northern Pacific Ocean. This large species may grow up to one meter (over three feet) in length, though most are only 47 centimeters (18 inches) long. Its prominent snout and small chin barbels distinguish it from other local rattail fishes.

node.text:
Selfcare Sunday—deep-sea edition 🧘🏽⁠
⁠
It's National Relaxation Day, and we're taking a moment to de-stress with our favorite deep-sea girl gang. MBARI researchers continue to study the famed Octopus Garden site on the edge of Davidson Seamount—an underwater mountain made of ancient lava. These octopuses (Muusoctopus robustus) were observed tucked into crevices in the lava seafloor, each one carefully guarding the developing eggs underneath. ⁠This is the only place scientists have ever seen such a large aggregation of brooding octopuses anywhere in the world.⁠⁠

A rare view of our favorite deep-sea eel. ⁠🤩⁠
⁠
This gulper eel, Saccopharynx lavenbergi, allowed us a head-on view of its amazing face with ROV Doc Ricketts. Gulper eels have a mouth that is loosely hinged and can be opened wide enough to swallow a fish much larger itself and the stomach can stretch to accommodate large meals, although stomach content analysis suggests they primarily eat small crustaceans.

node.text:
How to accessorize in the deep sea. ⁠
⁠
Crinoids, with their elegant, flower-like appearance, are commonly known as feather stars and sea lilies. MBARI's remotely operated vehicles have observed several different crinoid species at depths ranging from shallow waters to deep areas on the seafloor from the Aleutian Islands off Alaska to Baja California, Mexico. They use their feathery arms to capture small plankton drifting in the currents. The food is then moved to the mouth, which faces up in the center of the arms. ⁠
⁠
These feather stars are growing on top of a gorgeous Heterochone sponge in the Pacific Northwest.

node.text:
This is one alluring fish. 🎣⁠
⁠
The northern giant seadevil anglerfish (Ceratias holboelli) is one of the largest of all the deep-sea anglerfishes. Females may grow up to 1.2 meters (four feet) in length, though most are only 77 centimeters (over two feet) long. MBARI’s ROV Ventana encountered this individual at almost 500 meters (1,600 feet) deep in Monterey Bay.

Deep-sea SpongeBob⁠
⁠
Sponges are generally filter feeders, living off of bacteria and single-celled organisms sieved from the surrounding water. They contain specialized cells called choancytes, whose whip-like tails move continuously to create a flow of water that brings food to the sponge. But sponges can have a variety of shapes, sizes, and colors. This sponge is perched on a stalk above the seafloor 2,800 meters (over 9,000 feet) deep off the coast of Oregon.

node.text:
Fresh from the deep: a whalefish made an appearance for our researchers last week! ⁠
⁠
This whalefish (order Cetomimiformes) was spotted by Steve Haddock and his team on their recent R/V Western Flyer expedition 2,013 meters (6,600 feet) deep offshore of Monterey Bay. We've only encountered these obscure fish 16 times in 34 years of deep-sea exploration with our remotely operated vehicles (ROVs). ⁠
⁠
Whalefishes lack external scales and pelvic fins, and in adult fish, the eyes are very primitive and small. The eyes' lenses are lost after they transform from the larval stage, and with it, they lose the ability to form images. But instead of relying on sight to survive, they have an incredible ability to feel their surrounding. They have a highly sensitive lateral line system, with sensory pores that run over the head and down the length of the body to help them feel vibrations in the water around them. ⁠
⁠
Whalefish have rarely been seen alive in the deep, so many mysteries remain regarding these remarkable fish. With each deep-sea dive, we uncover more secrets and solve others. ⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by MBARI on August 09, 2021 tagging @montereybayaquarium.

node.text:
Kelp forest roll-call! ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Counting species in marine environments isn't as easy as calling out names, but researchers at MBARI are up for the challenge! Assessing biodiversity—the abundance of individuals and species—is critical for understanding an ecosystem. But in the ocean, taking stock of what lives beneath the surface presents several challenges. Now, researchers from @ucsantabarbara and MBARI have shown that drifting bits of genetic material called environmental DNA, or eDNA, can be a valuable tool for monitoring coastal ecosystems.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
For almost 20 years, researchers at the Santa Barbara Coastal Long-Term Ecological Research site have conducted detailed censuses of the majestic kelp forests off Santa Barbara’s coast. But each census requires divers to conduct underwater visual surveys or to deploy and monitor special equipment. Now, eDNA can be a new tool for detecting which species live in these lush underwater forests. Learn more on our website (#linkinbio). Images: @montereybayaquarium and @sbc_lter

Photo shared by MBARI on August 09, 2021 tagging @sbc_lter. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Even the tiniest of deep-sea denizens are spectacular! 🌈
⁠
This tiny jelly, Arctapodema sp., is only a few centimeters wide and is typically found from a few hundred meters in the deep sea all the way to our ROV's depth capability—4,000 meters (13,120 feet)! ⁠
⁠
Jellies like this one reproduce by asexually budding new polyps. Swipe and take a close look inside the bell and you can see a baby jelly clinging to the manubrium (the tubular structure in the center that contains the mouth). The rainbow of colors in this image is caused by the light from our ROV diffracting through the jelly's transparent tissue.

node.text:
Deep-sea still life. 🖌️⁠
⁠
Soft corals, like the one in the center of this video clip, may resemble stony corals but don't have their distinctive stony skeleton. This soft coral, known as the mushroom coral, Heteropolypus ritteri, lives off the coast of California and Mexico to depths as great as 3,000 meters (nearly two miles). They have polyps with only eight tentacles and those beautiful tentacles contain poisonous stinging cells that capture tiny animals drifting by. It gets its name because when the polyps are pulled in, it looks like a mushroom!

She's got those deep-sea eyes 👀⁠
⁠
Many midwater organisms have unusual eyes. Hyperiid amphipods have a particularly impressive range of diverse eye types, with a minimum of 10 different eye configurations, from minuscule eyes in some species that eke out a living in perpetual darkness to quite dramatic eyes in others that experience at least some sunlight. In this image, you can see a close-up lab shot of a species of Paraphronima. Photo by Bill Browne on the R/V Western Flyer.
